I simply couldn't be prouder of our PPHS students. The State requires certain presentations yearly by the Counseling Depatment. Even if they didn't require it, it would be an important and necessary discussion to have annually.

This week I covered Bullying and Harassment with all students in all grades (students not at school were included by broadcast).

It can be a serious and deep discussion since bullying and harassment (if they meet the legal thresh holds) are now against state and federal law. The consequences can be steep. Of course, we also talked about the impact on those bullied, from fear, to negative impact on learning, to possible self-harm. 100% of the students took it seriously. Not once in 26 presentations of 400 and something students did a student need to be called down or corrected. They took such serious information...welll..seriously.

Our students really do care about each other and I watched their eagerness to learn how to treat each other better in class after class. It was a long week but I couldn't be prouder to be a Bearcat!

Just A Good Kid...Coleton Beathard

If you say the name "Coleton Beathard" to his teachers, they're not going to say a single bad thing about him. However, those same teachers are going to shake their heads and smile. Coleton is a character. He's sharp, he's witty, and he is as ornery as the day is long. For a lot of us, kids like Coleton are our favorite type of kid to have in class. You love him, but you'd better keep your head on a swivel and watch him too!

Coleton is a senior, and has been heavily involved with both athletics and FFA. He has played baseball all four years of high school, football for three years, and was in powerlifting for one year. Coleton was even a state qualifier on our Bass Fishing team, something that he has been active in for three years. He has also been a part of our Ag Mech team and Equine team.

Coleton is absolutely one that we're going to hate to see go. Once he graduates in May, Coleton wants to go straight to the workforce and become a lineman.

Keep up the good work, Coleton!

-Mr. Southard

Just A Good Kid...Hope McNeese

If you want to talk about the best of the best around here, Hope McNeese comes up in that discussion. Hope is a fantastic kid, and you're going to have a hard time finding any better.

Hope is a senior, and she moved here her junior year. What an addition! She fit right in as soon as she got here. An incredibly hard worker; she's currently in the top ten percent of her class. She plays basketball, where she serves as a team captain, plays golf, is involved with UIL Social Studies and FCCLA, and also serves as the PPHS Yearbook editor.

After high school, Hope wants to attend the University of Kansas and major in secondary education, with a focus on history. After that, she wants to become a history teacher--and she'll make a great one!

Hope, keep up the good work!

-Mr. Southard

A few months ago, Dravyn Stanley got mad at us. And, as is always the case, he let us know about it, "You haven't bragged on me on Facebook!" So we made a deal; no problems...pass all your classes...we brag.

Well, he did it! Dravyn, a deal's a deal.

Truth be told, Dravyn is a favorite around here for a lot of reasons. One, he is funny as all get out, and he is incredibly fun to pick on (it doesn't take much to set him off). Most importantly, he's a kid that has really come on the last year or so. He gets along with everyone. He never gets into trouble at all, and he'll always do what you ask him to do. Oh, he'll gripe, but he'll do it. He is honest to a fault and it's really hard not to like the kid a lot.

Dravyn, keep up the good work. We are proud of you!

-Mr. Southard

Just A Good Kid...McKenzie Watland

When you talk about the best of the best around PPHS, McKenzie Watland's name always gets thrown into the mix. McKenzie is a senior, and she is certainly one that we're going to hate to see go. She's sharp, she's a hard worker, and the thing I've always been impressed with the most about McKenzie is that she's incredibly level-headed, fair, and honest. Everyone loves this kid.

McKenzie has had a stellar high school career. She's the president of the National Honor Society, carrying a 4.0. She has 30-plus hours of dual credit, is a member of Student Council, and competes in FFA on the Skills Team. She has also been a cheerleader for four years, serving as a captain for two years.

But the thing McKenzie's most proud of? She'll be the first in her family to attend college. She has just recently been accepted to Ole Miss.

Congratulations, McKenzie!

-Mr. Southard
